main event: Two fighter pilots at Clark Air Force Base observed an irregular mass with the appearance of a flak burst sitting still in the atmosphere, connected to a curved trail of corkscrew appearance on 17 November 1948.
interesting points: The object had the appearance of a flak burst sitting still in the atmosphere, connected to a curved trail of corkscrew appearance, judged to be from one to ten miles in length.
The trail did not have the appearance of a vapor trail but rather that of rocket or jet exhaust at an altitude above 20,000 and under 50,000 feet.
The mass and trail disappeared within approximately three minutes.
The object was estimated to be at an altitude of 30,000 feet and was white in color, resembling an exhaust trail with a sudden burst origin.
The sighting occurred despite clear weather and a cloudless sky in the vicinity.
The report was evaluated as C-3 by the Thirteenth Air Force.
The time of day of the observation was in agreement with the nature of the sighting.
No sound was reported to be made by the object.
The mass appeared to be at an altitude of approximately 30,000 feet and had the appearance of an aircraft's exploded white smoke column.
The object's disappearance involved its trail evaporating after three minutes, scattering thinly throughout the atmosphere.
sighted object: irregular mass with the appearance of a flak burst connected to a corkscrew-shaped trail
witnesses: Two fighter pilots of the Thirteenth Air Force
photographs: no photographs available in the report
